In heterogeneous catalysis, achieving well-dispersed and highly active noble metal/support catalysts through strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) remains a key challenge. Conventional SMSI generation via high-temperature reduction or oxidation often leads to noble metal nanoparticles (NPs) agglomeration, compromising catalytic performance. In this work, we construct SMSI in a Ru/CeO2-S catalyst through phase transformation of a Ru4 + /Ce-precursor (Ce(OH)CO3) during high-temperature reduction, effectively preventing Ru NP sintering. The introduction of SMSI leads to Ru NPs being encapsulated by a CeO2 layer, enhancing stability. We systematically investigate the SMSI formation mechanism and its influencing factors, such as the geometric coating degree of the Ru surface, oxygen vacancy concentration, and CO adsorption behavior. Compared to the conventional Ru/CeO2 catalyst synthesized via impregnation (Ru/CeO2-T), the Ru/CeO2-S catalyst exhibits superior sintering resistance and stability for CO oxidation. Notably, it maintains its initial catalytic performance even after calcination at 700 °C in air, attributed to the enhanced SMSI effect. This work offers a strategic approach for designing stable, high-performance Ce-based noble metal catalysts. Graphical Abstract Keywords CeO2 Ru nanoparticles Strong metal-support interaction CO oxidation Sinter-resistant Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Supported metal catalysts, featuring metal nanoparticles (NPs) dispersed on supports with high surface area, offer numerous advantages including superior metal dispersion, cost efficiency, enhanced stability, and recyclability. These catalysts are widely utilized in heterogeneous catalytic processes such as CO oxidation, hydrocracking of waste plastic, CH4 reforming, CO2 hydrogenation, and selective catalytic reduction (SCR) denitrification [1]. Common synthesis methods, including wet-impregnation and co-precipitation, are typically used for fabricating these catalysts [2]. However, merely depositing metal NPs onto a support is insufficient to prevent their migration and sintering at elevated temperatures, which can significantly degrade their catalytic activity. Since Tauster et al.’s discovery that the high-temperature reduction treatment in the Pt-TiO2 system alters the ability of the catalyst to chemically adsorb small molecules such as H2 and CO, the concept of strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) emerged and has been thoroughly investigated [3]. Subsequent studies have demonstrated that SMSI not only stabilizes metal NPs but also plays a vital role in modulating catalytic performance [4]. To date, numerous strategies have been devised to create and strengthen SMSI between metals and diverse supports. The nature of SMSI has been elucidated through investigations into the encapsulation of metal NPs by supports, with a specific consideration of geometric factors [5]. The conventional strategy for inducing SMSI in metal-metal oxide systems involves H2-reduction [6,7]. For instance, Tang et al. demonstrated that high-temperature H2 reduction significantly enhanced SMSI in an Au/TiO2 catalyst [6]. The formation of a TiOx layer encapsulating the Au NPs contributed to the outstanding catalyst stability during CO oxidation. In addition, high-temperature O2 oxidation has also been extensively explored as a route to induce SMSI [8–10]. Liu et al. discovered the SMSI effect in the Au/ZnO catalyst after O2 treatment, marked by the encapsulation of Au NPs with ZnO and electron transfer between ZnO and Au [8]. More recently, Wang et al. constructed SMSI in the Au NPs/Mg-Al layered double oxides (Au/LDO) without involving the reduction and oxidation processes [11]. Instead, calcination of Au/layered double hydroxide under N2 triggered a hydroxide-to-oxide transformation, leading to LDO encapsulation of Au NPs. This structure exhibited exceptional resistance to sintering at elevated temperatures. These findings provide valuable insights into designing supported metal catalysts with superior stability and catalytic activity. However, extending these principles to broader material systems and deepening the comprehension of SMSI remain crucial challenges in the field. Recently, the SMSI in metal/cerium oxide (CeO2) catalysts has attracted significant attention owing to unique properties of CeO2, including its high oxygen storage and release capability, controllable oxygen vacancy concentration, and the existence of a narrow Ce band. For example, Matte et al. demonstrated SMSI between CeO2 supports and Ni NPs following H2 reduction [12]. Subsequent characterization revealed a CeO2 layer coating Ni NPs, providing direct evidence for the geometric factor of SMSI. Although SMSI has been widely reported to enhance catalytic activity for active metals (such as Pt, Rh, Pd, Ni, and Ir) on CeO2, achieving similar geometric encapsulation of SMSI in the Ru-CeO2 system remains challenging through conventional high-temperature calcination [13,14]. This limitation arises because the formation of geometric coating layers is closely related to temperature. When support species migrate to the surface of metal NPs under thermal drive, metal NPs may undergo sintering at high temperatures due to Ostwald ripening or migration-bonding. Therefore, regulating the thermal decomposition behavior of the support precursor is critical to balance the formation of the geometric coating layer on metal NPs against their migration and sintering, and is also a prerequisite for building a robust SMSI system. Herein, we developed a strategy to induce SMSI between CeO2 support and Ru NPs by leveraging the phase transformation of the Ce(OH)CO3 precursor to CeO2 during catalyst synthesis (denoted as Ru/CeO2-S). Initially, Ru species were deposited onto the surface of the Ce(OH)CO3 precursor through impregnation. Subsequently, high-temperature H2 reduction induced a phase transformation of Ce(OH)CO3 to CeO2, concurrently reducing the Ru species to form Ru NPs. This phase transformation process generated a characteristic SMSI encapsulation structure, with a CeO2 layer covering the Ru NPs. The formation mechanism of SMSI was elucidated by analyzing CeO2 support reconstruction, activation, and migration during the phase transformation process, alongside the geometric coating degree and electronic effects on the Ru surface. Remarkably, even after calcination at 700 ℃ in air, the Ru/CeO2-S catalyst still maintained its initial catalytic performance for CO oxidation. This finding demonstrates that the Ru/CeO2-S catalyst achieved significantly enhanced thermal stability compared to the conventional Ru/CeO2-T catalyst prepared by impregnation, demonstrating the effectiveness of this precursor-mediated SMSI engineering approach. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Nitrosyl ruthenium nitrate (Ru(NO)(NO3)3, Ru ≥ 31.3 %) was purchased from Shanghai Yuanye Biotechnology Co. Ltd. Ethanol (C2H6O, 99.7 %), cerium nitrate (Ce(NO3)3·6 H2O, 99.0 %), quartz sand (SiO2), and urea (CH4N2O, 99.0 %) were ordered from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent. All the chemicals were commercially available and used as received. Throughout the whole experiment, deionized water (> 18.2 MΩ·cm−1) was used. 2.2 Synthesis of Ce(OH)CO3 precursor The Ce(OH)CO3 precursor was synthesized via a hydrothermal method [15]. Typically, 1.042 g of Ce(NO3)3·6 H2O and 0.384 g of urea were thoroughly dissolved in 80 mL of deionized water. Subsequently, the resulting solution was sealed in a 100 mL autoclave and heated in an oven at 120 °C for 8 h. The white precipitate was obtained after purification by centrifugation and washing with water, and then dried overnight at 80 °C. 2.3 Synthesis of Ru/CeO2-S catalyst The Ru/CeO2-S catalyst was synthesized by wet impregnation method using Ce(OH)CO3 precursor as a support. Typically, 124.9 mg of Ce(OH)CO3 precursor was dispersed in 3 mL of water. Then, 0.1 mL of Ru(NO)(NO3)3 solution (100 mM) was dissolved in 4 mL of water, slowly added to the above precursor dispersion, and stirred for 24 h. After impregnation and drying, the sample was further dried in a vacuum oven at 120 ℃ overnight. Subsequently, the dried sample was calcined in 10 % H2/N2 (50 mL min−1) at 600 ℃ (heating rate: 10 ℃ min−1) for 3 h to obtain the Ru/CeO2-S catalyst. Finally, the Ru/CeO2-S catalyst was further calcined in air to 700 °C (heating rate: 5 °C·min−1) and kept at this temperature for 2 h to obtain the Ru/CeO2-S-A700 catalyst. 2.4 Synthesis of Ru/CeO2-T catalyst The Ru/CeO2-T catalyst was synthesized by wet impregnation using CeO2 as a support. First, the CeO2 support was prepared by calcining the Ce(OH)CO3 precursor in 10 % H2/N2 (50 mL min−1) at 600 ℃ for 3 h. Then, 0.1 mL of Ru(NO)(NO3)3 solution (100 mM) was dissolved in 4 mL of water, mixed with 100 mg of the CeO2 support, and stirred for 24 h. After impregnation and drying, the sample was further dried in a vacuum oven at 120 ℃ overnight. Subsequently, the dried sample was heated in 10 % H2/N2 (50 mL min−1) to 400 °C (heating rate: 10 °C min−1) for 2 h to obtain the Ru/CeO2-T catalyst. Finally, the Ru/CeO2-T catalyst was further heated in air to 700 °C (heating rate: 5 °C·min−1) and kept at this temperature for 2 h to obtain the Ru/CeO2-T-A700 catalyst. 2.5 Measurement of catalytic CO oxidation performance The catalytic performance of the catalysts for CO oxidation was tested using an atmospheric continuous-flow fixed-bed reactor. Typically, 30 mg of catalyst and 200 mg quartz sand were first placed onto the reactor and the system was purged with pure N2. Subsequently, the CO/O2/N2 mixed gas (50 mL min−1, 1:10:89 v/v%) was introduced into the system. Gasboard-3100 online infrared gas analyzer (Sifang Optoelectronics, China) was used to analyze the components of CO and CO2 online. Determined CO conversion (ICO) using the following Eq. (1): (1) I CO = 1 − X CO X CO * × 100 % Where XCO and XCO* are the CO content before and after the catalytic reaction, respectively. At the reaction temperature (T) evaluated, the turnover frequency (TOF, the number of turnovers of a single active site per unit time) of the catalyst was determined by (2): (2) TOF = PV RT × W co × X co N R u where T, R, V, P and WCO stood for reaction temperature (K), molar gas constant (8.314 J mol−1 s−1), the flow rate (50 mL min−1), the pressure (1.01 ×105 Pa), and volume percentage of CO (1 %), respectively, of the input gas. NRu was the mole mass of Ru in catalysts as measured. It is noteworthy that, to maintain the initial reaction rate within the kinetic range, calculations were focused on data points with a conversion rate below 10 %. 2.6 Characterizations The crystalline structure and phase purity of the catalysts were analyzed using an X-ray powder diffraction (XRD, Japan Rigaku D/Max-γA) with Cu Kα radiation (λ=1.54 Å). The size and structure of catalysts were investigated by transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL 2100 F). High-angle annular dark field-scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) elemental mapping were employed for a more in-depth analysis of the structure and elemental distribution. Surface valence states of samples were studied using an X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) (Thermo Scientific K-Alpha) with an Al Kα source. Raman spectra were investigated on a LabRAM HR800 spectrometer using a 523 nm excitation laser. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of catalysts were tested at 77 K on a Micromeritics TriStar II 3020 analyzer. Pore size distributions of samples were analyzed from the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) desorption branches of the isotherms. Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) measurements were conducted on a PCA-1200 chemisorption analyzer. 50 mg of catalyst was used and heated in a 10 % H2/Ar mixture gas flow (10 °C min−1). All catalysts were pretreated with N2 for 60 min in an in situ diffuse reflectance cell before CO-diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) testing. After the background was collected and the adsorption of CO was saturated, N2 was passed through for purging treatment. Then, reaction gas was introduced to perform the in situ oxidation reaction and the spectrum was recorded. The WO3 color change experiment was performed by completely mixing 180 mg of WO3 and 20 mg of the catalyst, then transferring the mixture into a quartz tube and observing and recording the color change of WO3 in a H2 atmosphere at 80 °C. 3 Results and discussion To induce SMSI in the Ru/CeO2 catalyst, we designed a synthesis strategy predicated on a support phase transformation process. Ce(OH)CO3 nanorods were selected as the support precursor because high-temperature treatment induces their transformation to CeO2 and the formation of a porous structure. As illustrated in Scheme 1, Ru4+ ions were first loaded onto the Ce(OH)CO3 precursor via impregnation. Subsequent H2 reduction treatment at 600 ℃ transformed the precursor into the Ru/CeO₂-S catalyst, characterized by a CeO2 support with abundant oxygen vacancies and metallic Ru NPs encapsulated within a CeO2 layer. In contrast, a conventional Ru/CeO2-T catalyst was synthesized by impregnating Ru NPs onto a CeO2 support derived from high-temperature reduction treatment of the Ce(OH)CO3 precursor. To further evaluate the sintering resistance, both Ru/CeO2 catalysts underwent calcination in air at 700 ℃ and were designated as Ru/CeO2-S-A700 and Ru/CeO2-T-A700, respectively. The crystal structure and purity of the catalysts were analyzed by XRD. As shown in Fig. 1, the distinct peaks of the as-prepared catalysts at 28.5°, 33.2°, 47.6°, 56.5°, and 59.2° are in good consistent with the (111), (200), (220), and (311) crystal planes of fluorite cubic CeO2, respectively [16]. The absence of Ce(OH)CO3 diffraction peaks indicates its complete transformation into CeO2 (Fig. S1). It is worth noting that no detectable RuO2 or Ru-related diffraction peaks in either the as-prepared Ru/CeO2-S and Ru/CeO2-T catalysts or even their calcined counterparts at high temperatures, indicating that Ru NPs were uniformly distributed on the CeO2 [17,18]. The colors of Ru/CeO2-S and Ru/CeO2-T catalysts are gray or black, similar to the color of the oxygen vacancy-rich CeO2 support (Fig. S2). However, after calcination in air, the color of Ru/CeO2-S-A700 and Ru/CeO2-T-A700 catalysts exhibited minimal change. In contrast, the CeO2 support with abundant oxygen vacancies turned light-yellow, indicative of a partial loss of oxygen vacancies. This observation further confirms the existence of Ru NPs in both Ru/CeO2-S and Ru/CeO2-T catalysts (Fig. S3). The morphology and structure of catalysts were examined using TEM. As shown in Fig. S4a, the Ce(OH)CO3 precursor presented a microrod-like structure with lengths around 12 μm. Apparently, Ru/CeO2 catalysts inherited the microrod morphology of the Ce(OH)CO3 precursor (Fig. S4b-c). Moreover, high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images of the Ru/CeO2-S catalyst reveal the presence of a closely interaction interface between uniformly sized Ru NPs (< 5 nm) and CeO2, attributed to the formation of a geometric coating ( Fig. 2a and b). This result suggests that following the reduction of the Ru4+/Ce(OH)CO3 sample at 600 °C, the in-situ reduced Ru NPs were completely coated by a CeO2 layer during the phase transformation process of the precursor. HAADF-STEM imaging and EDS elemental mapping provide additional confirmation of the even distribution of Ce, O, and Ru throughout the Ru/CeO2-S catalyst (Fig. S5a). While the Ru/CeO2-T catalyst also exhibited uniformly sized Ru NPs and even distribution of elements, no discernible geometric coating layer of CeO2 was found on the surface of Ru NPs (Fig. 2c and d, and S5b). After high-temperature treatment at 700 °C in air, the encapsulated coating remained intact. However, the size of Ru NPs in Ru/CeO2-S-A700 increased to approximately 10 nm (Fig. 2e and f). In contrast, the size of exposed Ru NPs in Ru/CeO2-T-A700 increased to over 20 nm. Therefore, these results further support that the phase transformation of Ce(OH)CO3 precursors builds geometric encapsulation coatings on Ru NPs surfaces, thereby significantly enhancing the sintering resistance of Ru NPs. In addition, for Ru/CeO2-S, the formed coating of CeO2 on Ru NPs is irreversible in an oxidizing atmosphere, which is different from the classical SMSI model. This behavior might be attributed to the complete coverage of well-dispersed Ru NPs by CeO2 and/or relatively higher stability of CeO2 compared to other metal oxides under high-temperature oxidizing conditions [11,19]. These observations highlight a distinct departure from conventional SMSI construction strategies. N2 adsorption-desorption measurements were used to determine the surface area and pore size of Ru/CeO2 catalysts. As depicted in Fig. S6a, both Ru/CeO2-S and Ru/CeO2-T catalysts exhibited type IV isotherms with typical H3-type hysteresis loops, comfirming their mesoporous nature [20]. The BJH pore size distributions revealed a concentrated distribution of pore sizes between 2.0 and 10.0 nm for both catalysts. Moreover, based on Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) measurements, the Ru/CeO2-S and Ru/CeO2-T catalysts exhibited similar BET properties, with specific surface areas of 13.4 and 13.8 m2 g–1, pore volume of 0.060 cm3 g–1 for both, and average pore size of 18.0 and 17.5 nm, respectively (Table S1). These results indicate that the specific surface areas and pore structures of these catalysts were unaffected by different treatment sequences of the precursor. In addition, after high-temperature treatment in air, the specific surface areas of both Ru/CeO2-S-A700 and Ru/CeO2-T-A700 decreased slightly, attributable to the decrease in pore volume caused by the elevated temperature (Table S1). Raman spectroscopy was conducted to explore the interfacial interaction between Ru NPs and the CeO2 support in the Ru/CeO2 catalysts. As indicated in Fig. S7, a main peak for the CeO2 support was observed at 463.8 cm–1, corresponding to the Ce–O symmetric stretching vibration (F2 g mode) of the cubic ﬂuorite structure [21]. After the introduction of 1.0 wt% Ru, the F2 g peak of Ru/CeO2 catalysts red-shifts to 456.0 cm–1 ( Fig. 3a). These significant red-shifts observed in catalysts are related to the Ce–O bonding interaction, resulting from electron transfer from Ru to the CeO2 support [22]. In addition, the two minor peaks at 243.0 and 597.0 cm–1 correspond to the second-order transverse acoustic mode and defect-induced mode (D) of the fluorite phase CeO2, respectively (Fig. 3b) [23]. After loading Ru NPs on CeO2 support, two additional peaks appeared at 695.0 and 970.0 cm–1, assigned to the Ru–O–Ce bond, arising from the formation of SMSI. The integrated area ratio (ID/IF2g) of the D peak to the F2 g peak provides a quantitative measure of the oxygen vacancy concentration [24]. In comparison to the pure CeO2 support, the Ru/CeO2 catalysts exhibited higher ID/IF2g ratios owing to the pronounced interactions between Ru NPs and the CeO2 support [25]. Specifically, the Ru/CeO2-S and Ru/CeO2-S-A700 catalysts exhibited ID/IF2g ratios of 0.15 and 0.14, respectively, slightly higher than those of Ru/CeO2-T and Ru/CeO2-T-A700, which showed ratios of 0.08 and 0.05, respectively. These results indicate that the Ru/CeO2-S catalyst has a higher oxygen vacancy concentration owing to the strong interactions between Ru NPs and the CeO2 support. H2-TPR was performed on the catalysts to study the reducibility of surface oxygen, with the corresponding results presented in Fig. 3c. The low-temperature reduction peaks observed between 116 and 144 °C for both Ru/CeO2-S and Ru/CeO2-T catalysts are attributed to the reduction of RuO2 species. The additional reduction peak located at 96 °C for Ru/CeO2-S, in comparison to Ru/CeO2-T, is assigned to RuOx species associated with SMSI, including Ru–O–Ce and Ru species activating oxygen ions. This observation further indicates an enhanced interaction between Ru and CeO2 in the Ru/CeO2-S catalyst [26,27]. Although the strong interaction peak of Ru/CeO2-S appears at a lower temperature than that of Ru/CeO2-T, H2 consumption begins much earlier for Ru/CeO2-T. This indicates that the exposed Ru NPs in Ru/CeO2-T promote the formation of more surface RuOx species, facilitating its low-temperature CO oxidation activity. The reduction peaks observed between 213 and 253 °C correspond to the surface reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+, with the variation in reduction temperatures between Ru/CeO2-S and Ru/CeO2-T catalysts may be caused by the different chemical coordination states of Ru species [18]. In addition, after thermal treatment at 700 ℃, the reduction peaks of Ru/CeO2-S-A700 and Ru/CeO2-T-A700 catalysts shifted to higher temperatures of 141 and 163 ℃, respectively. The reduction peak of Ru/CeO2-S-A700 at 96 ℃ disappeared, indicating RuOx species gradually transformed into well-dispersed RuO2 species. This transformation weakened the Ru–CeO2 interaction, consistent with the observed increase in particle size from TEM. However, the red-shifted reduction peak of RuO2 species in Ru/CeO2-T, attributed to the formation of well-crystallized RuO2, which requires a relatively higher temperature for reduction. In comparison to Ru/CeO2-T-A700, the lower reduction peak of RuO2 species in the Ru/CeO2-S-A700 catalyst further indicates the strong interaction within the Ru/CeO2-S catalyst. The elemental valence states and surface composition of Ru/CeO2 catalysts were studied by XPS. The Ce 3d spectra of the as-prepared Ru/CeO2 catalysts exhibit characteristic spin-orbit doublets corresponding to the 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 electronic configurations ( Fig. 4a and b). The characteristic peaks at 885.2 and 903.8 eV are assigned to Ce3+, while those at 882.4, 900.9, 888.7, 907.6, 898.3, and 916.7 eV are attributed to Ce4+ [21]. The relative concentrations of Ce3+ species in Ru/CeO2-S, Ru/CeO2-T, Ru/CeO2-S-A700, and Ru/CeO2-T-A700 catalysts, determined from the integrated peak areas of deconvolution peaks, were calculated to be 12.8 %, 12.0 %, 12.6 %, and 11.4 %, respectively. These findings indicate that a higher number of oxygen vacancies were generated in the Ru/CeO2-S catalyst, even after calcination at 700 ℃ in air. The O 1 s spectra was resolved into two distinct peaks: the lower binding energy peak at 529.4 corresponding to lattice oxygen (Olat), and the higher energy peak at 531.4 eV attributed to surface-adsorbed oxygen species (Oads) (Fig. 4c and d) [28]. Calculated from the integrated areas of resolved peaks, the Oads/(Oads + Olat) ratio of Ru/CeO2-S is 58.2 %, higher than that of Ru/CeO2-T (52.4 %) (Table S2). This indicates a higher oxygen vacancy concentration in the Ru/CeO2-S catalyst. Furthermore, following calcination at 700 ℃, the Ru/CeO2-S-A700 catalyst exhibited a 13.2 % reduction in Oads/(Oads + Olat) ratio, significantly less than the 23.9 % decrease for the Ru/CeO2-T-A700 catalyst. This result solidifies the evidence supporting the remarkable stability of the Ru/CeO2-S catalyst. Figs. 4e and 4f show the Ru 3d5/2 spectra of Ru/CeO2 catalysts before and after calcination at 700 ℃ in air, respectively. The Ru 3d5/2 spectra could be resolved into three peaks located at 280.0, 280.8, and 282.1 eV, assigned to Ru0, Ru4+, and Run+ (4 < n < 6), respectively [29]. As per the calculated results presented in Table S2, the integral area ratio of Run+/(Ru0 + Ru4+ + Run+) in catalysts follows the sequence of Ru/CeO2-S (31.8 %) > Ru/CeO2-S-A700 (29.7 %) > Ru/CeO2-T (26.2 %) > Ru/CeO2-T-A700 (20.7 %). The Run+ species was reported to be distinct from RuO2 and RuO3, which may be due to electron transfer from Ru to the CeO2 support or creation of Ru–O–Ce bonds at the interface [26,30–32]. Therefore, the Ru/CeO2-S catalyst demonstrated the highest concentration of positively charged Ru on the surface, and there was a strong contact between its support and the noble metal interface. Moreover, even after high-temperature oxidation treatment, the Run+/(Ru0 + Ru4+ + Run+) ratio of the obtained Ru/CeO2-S-A700 catalyst decreased, but it was still higher than that of Ru/CeO2-T and Ru/CeO2-T-A700 catalysts, unequivocally demonstrating the pronounced SMSI effect in Ru/CeO2-S. In addition, the smaller decrease in Run+ content after calcination for Ru/CeO2-S (2.1 %) compared to Ru/CeO2-T (5.5 %) provides further evidence for the enhanced stability of the Ru/CeO2-S catalyst. The catalytic performance of the Ru/CeO2 catalysts was evaluated through CO oxidation as a probe reaction, with the corresponding results presented in Fig. 5. For comparison purposes, we also evaluated the CO oxidation activity of pure CeO2 nanorods (Fig. S8). Fig. 5a shows that the Ru/CeO2-S and Ru/CeO2-T catalysts exhibited T50 (the temperature for 50 % conversion) and T100 of 172 and 270 °C, and 128 and 170 °C, respectively. These values are notably superior to those of pure CeO2 nanorods. Although the Ru/CeO2-S catalyst exhibited slightly lower CO oxidation activity due to the CeO2 coating on Ru NPs, its activation energy (Ea=52.8 kJ mol–1) is close to the Ru/CeO2-T catalyst (Ea=51.5 kJ mol–1) (Fig. 5b). This result suggests their similar reaction mechanism, however, the geometric coating in Ru/CeO2-S catalyst limits reactants accessibility to the active sites, thereby influencing the reaction rate. As expected, after thermal treatment at 700 °C in air, the Ru/CeO2-T-A700 catalyst exhibited a significantly decreased catalytic activity owing to the sintering of exposed Ru NPs (Fig. 5a). However, the Ru/CeO2-S-A700 catalyst showed no significant activity loss compared to the Ru/CeO2-S catalyst. Additionally, the activation energy of the Ru/CeO2-T catalyst increased from 51.5 to 60.9 kJ mol–1 after calcination at 700 ℃ in air (Ru/CeO2-T-A700). However, the activation energy of the Ru/CeO2-S catalyst slightly increased from 52.8 to 56.5 kJ mol–1 (Ru/CeO2-S-A700). These increased activation energies suggest a shift in the rate-determining step. The high-temperature calcination caused Ru sintering, leading to a change in the surface structure of the Ru NPs, which could alter the adsorption geometry of CO, shifting the rate-determining step. Therefore, the phase transformation process of Ru/CeO2-S, fostering a strong interaction of SMSI between Ru and CeO2, resulted in a geometric coating that inhibited the exposure of Ru active sites and weakened the adsorption of CO molecules by Ru particles. At the same time, the stability of the geometric coating ensured the Ru/CeO2-S catalyst maintained excellent catalytic performance even after calcination at 700 °C in air. A long-term stability test was conducted on Ru/CeO2-S, Ru/CeO2-T, and Ru/CeO2-S-A700 catalysts over 42 h at 200 °C (Fig. 5c). In comparison to the initial stage, both Ru/CeO2-S and Ru/CeO2-S-A700 exhibited no significant decrease in CO conversion rate after 40 h. It is noteworthy that the Ru/CeO2-T catalyst exhibited a progressive decline in CO conversion following 30 h of the continuous catalytic reaction. Furthermore, given its inferior CO oxidation activity, the Ru/CeO2-T-A700 catalyst was subjected to long-term stability testing at an elevated temperature of 350 °C. Following 30 h of continuous catalytic reaction, the catalytic activity of the Ru/CeO2-T-A700 catalyst also began to notably decrease, mirroring the trend of the Ru/CeO2-T catalyst. Apart from the long-term stability test, Ru/CeO2-S and Ru/CeO2-T catalysts were also selected for cycle stability testing under identical CO catalytic conditions. The Ru/CeO2-S catalyst maintained approximately 100 % CO conversion even after six catalytic cycles, as shown in Fig. 5d. In sharp contrast, the Ru/CeO2-T catalyst exhibited activity degradation after just two catalytic reaction cycles. Through the preceding analysis, it can be inferred that Ru/CeO2-S achieved geometric encapsulation during the phase transformation process, effectively inhibiting the deactivation of the noble metal Ru NPs. However, the Ru/CeO2-T catalyst showed good activity due to the exposure of Ru NPs on the CeO2 surface, but is easily deactivated after calcination at 700 °C or long-term/cyclic use. Therefore, these results indicate that the Ru/CeO2-S catalyst with SMSI exhibited good durability even after calcination at 700 °C or long-term/cyclic use. In situ DRIFTS analysis was conducted on Ru/CeO2 catalysts, which were pretreated under N2 at 120 °C for 1 h, then exposed to CO for 0.5 h at room temperature, and finally purged with N2 ( Fig. 6). The adsorption peaks located at 2065, 2060, and 2054 cm−1 correspond to CO adsorbed on Run+ (Run+−(CO)x), while the adsorption peak at 1994 cm−1 is assigned to CO adsorbed on the Ru0 site at the Ru-CeO2 interface [33,34]. In addition, characteristic peaks observed at 2170 and 2116 cm−1 are attributed to the gaseous CO [35]. The linear adsorption of CO by Ru clusters with low coordination properties causes the adsorption peak (2065 cm−1) of the Ru/CeO2-S catalyst to shift towards the low frequency as the N2 blowing time increases (Fig. 6a). The chemical adsorption peak of CO adsorbed on the noble metal shifts to the low-frequency band due to SMSI is induced by electron donor centers and precious metal particles within the support [36]. Furthermore, a modest red-shift from 2065 to 2054 cm−1 was observed after Ru/CeO2-S was calcined at 700 °C in air (Fig. 6c). This red-shift is in line with the XPS results that show a decrease in oxidation state of Ru (Run+/Ru) [31]. In contrast, the Ru/CeO2-T catalyst exposed Ru NPs on the support surface, causing the CO molecules to fully come into contact with Ru and leading to a larger adsorption strength at 2060 cm−1 (Fig. 6b). The adsorption peak of CO adsorbed on Run+ also disappears after thermal treatment at 700 °C (Fig. 6d). Therefore, the high stability of Ru/CeO2-S was indirectly confirmed through the formation of SMSI geometric encapsulation. Exposure levels of Ru NPs in catalysts were indirectly compared using the WO3 color change test [37,38]. Under a H2 atmosphere, yellow WO3 undergoes reduction to form blue WO3-x at the temperatures above 200 °C. However, in the presence of a catalyst that can induce hydrogen overflow (such as a noble metal-loaded catalyst), yellow WO3 can undergo reduction to produce blue WO3-x at lower temperatures [39]. As shown in Fig. 7a, WO3 and the catalyst were thoroughly mixed before being placed in a quartz tube. After treatment with pure H2 at 80 °C for 30 min, neither Ru/CeO2-S nor Ru/CeO2-S-A700 cause significant color changes in WO3 (Fig. 7b), indicating that the Ru NPs of Ru/CeO2-S and Ru/CeO2-S-A700 catalysts were coated by the CeO2 layer, thereby limiting H2 dissociation to a certain extent. However, in comparison, as the H2 treatment time increased, the exposed Ru NPs of Ru/CeO2-T and Ru/CeO2-T-A700 catalysts without obvious encapsulation structure were conducive to the hydrogen overflow, thus gradually deepening the color of WO3. Therefore, these findings further indicate that the Ru/CeO2-S catalyst has a geometric encapsulation structure with the SMSI effect. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, we successfully developed a Ru/CeO2-S catalyst with SMSI driven by the phase transformation of Ru4+/Ce(OH)CO3 precursor during high-temperature reduction for CO oxidation. The induced SMSI resulted in the formation of a geometric encapsulation structure in which Ru NPs were coated with a thin CeO2 layer. To elucidate the SMSI formation mechanism, we performed comprehensive investigations of the geometric coating degree and electronic effects on the Ru surface, as well as the reconstruction, activation, and migration processes of CeO2 during phase transformation. More importantly, compared to the Ru/CeO2-T catalyst with exposed Ru NPs, the Ru/CeO2-S catalyst exhibited outstanding resistance to sintering and stability for CO oxidation. This work not only establishes the pyrolytic phase transformation of the Ce(OH)CO3 precursor as an effective strategy to induce SMSI but also provides valuable guidance for designing high-performance Ce-based noble metal catalysts through controlled structural evolution. coredata.dc:description: In heterogeneous catalysis, achieving well-dispersed and highly active noble metal/support catalysts through strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) remains a key challenge. Conventional SMSI generation via high-temperature reduction or oxidation often leads to noble metal nanoparticles (NPs) agglomeration, compromising catalytic performance. In this work, we construct SMSI in a Ru/CeO2-S catalyst through phase transformation of a Ru4 + /Ce-precursor (Ce(OH)CO3) during high-temperature reduction, effectively preventing Ru NP sintering. The introduction of SMSI leads to Ru NPs being encapsulated by a CeO2 layer, enhancing stability. We systematically investigate the SMSI formation mechanism and its influencing factors, such as the geometric coating degree of the Ru surface, oxygen vacancy concentration, and CO adsorption behavior. Compared to the conventional Ru/CeO2 catalyst synthesized via impregnation (Ru/CeO2-T), the Ru/CeO2-S catalyst exhibits superior sintering resistance and stability for CO oxidation. Notably, it maintains its initial catalytic performance even after calcination at 700 °C in air, attributed to the enhanced SMSI effect. This work offers a strategic approach for designing stable, high-performance Ce-based noble metal catalysts.
